unnormalised: Someone asked about time zone conversions, specifically between IST and other zones, so I thought I'd share some information. Converting between Indian Standard Time (IST) and other time zones can sometimes be tricky, particularly when daylight saving time (DST) is in effect in those other regions. IST, as you may know, is GMT+5:30, and India doesn't observe DST, which simplifies things on our end.
normalised: Someone asked about time zone conversions, specifically between I-S-T and other zones, so I thought I would share some information. Converting between Indian Standard Time (I-S-T) and other time zones can sometimes be tricky, particularly when daylight saving time (D-S-T) is in effect in those other regions. I-S-T, as you may know, is G-M-T plus five hours thirty minutes, and India doesn't observe D-S-T, which simplifies things on our end.

unnormalised: However, countries like the US or the UK do observe DST, typically from March to November. This means that the difference between IST and EDT (Eastern Daylight Time) isn't a constant 9 hrs 30 mins, but changes depending on the time of year. For example, from March 12th, 2023 to Nov 5th, 2023, the time difference might be only 9 hrs and 30 mins, then it shifts back to 10 hrs 30 mins. Always double-check the dates and specific offsets, which is easily done with a quick online search or time zone converter.
normalised: However, countries like the U-S or the U-K do observe D-S-T, typically from March to November. This means that the difference between I-S-T and E-D-T (Eastern Daylight Time) isn't a constant nine hours thirty minutes, but changes depending on the time of year. For example, from March twelfth, two thousand and twenty three to November fifth, two thousand and twenty three, the time difference might be only nine hours and thirty minutes, then it shifts back to ten hours thirty minutes. Always double-check the dates and specific offsets, which is easily done with a quick online search or time zone converter.

unnormalised: Moreover, some regions have unusual offsets. Nepal Standard Time (NPT) is GMT+5:45, a mere 15 minutes ahead of IST. Similarly, some parts of Australia have half-hour offsets, and their DST schedules vary greatly. When scheduling international meetings, I personally always try to use a tool like World Time Buddy or similar platforms that dynamically adjusts for these shifts; otherwise, the meeting at 10:00 AM EST on 16/11/2024 might find me prepping at 7:30 PM IST instead of relaxing after dinner.
normalised: Moreover, some regions have unusual offsets. Nepal Standard Time (N-P-T) is G-M-T plus five hours forty five minutes, a mere fifteen minutes ahead of I-S-T. Similarly, some parts of Australia have half-hour offsets, and their D-S-T schedules vary greatly. When scheduling international meetings, I personally always try to use a tool like World Time Buddy or similar platforms that dynamically adjusts for these shifts; otherwise, the meeting at ten A-M E-S-T on sixteenth November two thousand and twenty four might find me prepping at seven thirty P-M I-S-T instead of relaxing after dinner.

unnormalised: Finally, remember to specify the complete date and time, along with the time zone, to avoid any confusion. For instance, stating simply "Meeting at 2 PM" isn't enough. Saying "Meeting at 2:00 PM PST on 28/02/2024" provides clarity. Also, note the differences in date formats, like DD/MM/YYYY vs MM/DD/YYYY, to be extra safe. This ensures everyone's on the same page, irrespective of where they are located.
